body:
In order to pre-test the PRs by the community I suggest to create a public beta in a new branch.
There will be an apk, that experienced user can download, install and test.
This branch will contains all PRs that are "3 - to review" or above.
Issues regarding the beta will get the label "Beta".
Found bugs or improvements are implemented in the corresponding original PRs and merged back to beta.
The main advantage of this is, that the PRs are tested by far more user than "only" the QA. 
Furthermore if the PRs have fewer issues, the workload of the QA should be lower and thus can result in a faster merge process.

I am willing to maintain this branch and do a merge if the belonging PRs are changing.
What do you think? @davivel @rperezb @jancborchardt @AndyScherzinger @LukeOwncloud
title: Public Beta

body:
For security, I think 2FA is a must, TOTP should be sufficient. So that a compromised password isn't too big of an issue.

Also, would it be possible for the Android and Desktop clients to check the SSL certificate fingerprint?
Bassically, in the settings menu it should have a little information about the SSL certificate including the fingerprint. The app should give a warning when anything changed, that way MIT attacks are nearly impossible.

body:
If an attacker somehow find themselves in a position to inject script into a WebView, then they could exploit the opportunity to access local resources. This can be somewhat prevented by disabling local file system access. It is enabled by default. The Android WebSettings class can be used to disable local file system access via the public method setAllowFileAccess.

`webSettings().setAllowFileAccess(false);`

This restricts the WebView to loading local resources from file:///android_asset (assets) and file:///android_res (resources).
title: Disable File System Access in Webview Activity

body:
In a folder list and in a file list, accentuated letter are not considered properly to sort the folders/files.

For example, the letter "e" with accent "é" should be considered as a normal "e". But a folder or a file starting with "é" is sent to the end of the list, after "z".

Example:
- Étudiant should be before Radio
- Fé should be before Fr

It's the same for other accentuated letters (I didn't test all of them): í, à, ô, ù, ñ, ...
title: Accentuated letter are not sorted alphabetically

body:
The owncloud app is listed among the apps to share information whenever you choice to share something.  However,  most of the time the share fails,  since the owncloud app does not know how to handle the data.  This is really frustrating.  The most advantage purpose of having access to the owncloud server on an android device is the point that one is able to add very quickly content.. Owncloud on the go... 

The Owncloud app should therefore try to handle as much shared data as possible.  If there are multiple ways,  it could offer a selection.  E.g. saving as txt or odt. 
Furthermore,  the settings could define standard saving options.  E.g. Save in the folder notes/income/ save as $date-time-app-name.  
It should be possible to save text,  images,  videos, links,  html,  etc.  
An example how such a saving method could work would be the save dialogs of the firefox webbrowser, where one can simply save as default by a single click or allow customized saving settings.
title: Owncloud app should accept as many share content as possible

body:
I had a look at how we tag our stable releases, it seems like there is no clear scheme behind it. Most of the time it is ````oc-android-<version>```` which I think is a good way, but sometimes we add a arbitrary string at the end like ````oc-android-1.7.1-oem```` or ````oc-android-1.7.1_signed````. This prevent alternative app stores to build the packages automatically as you can see here https://gitlab.com/fdroid/fdroiddata/blob/master/metadata/com.owncloud.android.txt#L185

I think it would be great if you could decide on one default scheme and stick to it.
title: Tagging of stable releases

body:
Hello all,

I have posted my issue first in the forum, as I was not sure if I am experiencing a bug or if I am too bad to use the app correctly. It seems to be some buggy behavior.

I am using the current Sync App on Samsung S6 (Android 5.0.2) and on server side it is the newest/current ownCloud Server running on Linux Ubuntu.

I have two major issues uploading photos to folders I have created.

* Via the ownCloud App, browsing to the folder and then using the upload function.
This is kind of pain in the ***. When browsing the folders, when I choose the Camera, first of all, the photo list is always chronological, I have to go pass thousands of photos before having the ability to select the pictures I want. Also before clicking on "Upload", I need to way for all thumbnails to be displayed, otherwise the app will break/stop. So uploading one picture can be a matter of 5 minutes just wainting that thumbnails are built up.. 

* Via the image library and adding images to albums
I am not sure if this is an ownCloud feature. But in the image library I can select "Add to album" after selecting one or more photos. I discovered this quite late ;-) As there is no recognition symbol to ownCloud, I never paid attention to it. Also what is "bizar", the album list matches only 50% of the folder I have created on ownCloud, the other half is missing.. Anyways, I have selected 4 pictures and associated them to one of the albums. Now the photos are gone from the image library but are not in the ownCloud folders. They seem to be gone, deleted..

Additional info: While I was looking for the disappered photos and browsing the storage space, I noticed that the owncloud folder has a /tmp folder and a folde named like my account login. Some folders I have created where in the account folder, some others in the /tmp folder. I couldn't find out the logic behind this segmentation...

I would be glad to know if the client was designed to be like that or if it is seen as bug and will be enhanced in some next release?

Best regards,
MW
title: Photo upload issue and other ??

body:
There are some problems with routers that don't have NAT-Loopback if you want to upload/connect to your self-hosted owncloud.

Example case:
Owncloud local network (ip 192.168.1.100)
Owncloud global dns example.com (ip 90.50.100.30 )

if you want to connect over wifi (local network) to your owncloud and use example.com as url to it, then it will try to connect to 90.50.100.30 and it wont work. NAT-Loopback would lookup which ip you have and remap it to you local ip. 

Is there a possibility to get Advanced settings, on app side, where I can set the SSID (Wifi name) and the local ip to be able to connect through Wifi if I am connected to it?
I saw that on another app called Transdrone (see screenshots attached).
What do you guys think?

![screenshot_2015-04-28-10-41-45](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8521598/7365953/10b90eb4-ed95-11e4-9e18-2c3ecc2f18b8.png)

title: Connection problems with some routers over Wifi

body:
**UPDATE** - Temp workaround found:

**TL;DR:** They can't handle large storage sizes in their quota checks. Set a quota limit for your "Default Storage" value that just exceeds what you need. I put in 100GB.

--------------Original  ----------------------------------------------------------------------
I have just tested a copy of the 1.7.0 client and the 1.7.1 client.  It appears that there is some type of serious issue with 1.7.1 preventing "Refresh account" from working.

With my original install of OC Android 1.7.1 (upgraded via the Play Store over the past year) I could see a list of all my files, but I could not get a modified file to refresh its timestamp OR its content.

When I uninstalled 1.7.1 and installed FDroid 1.7.0 client, I lost my entire config of course, but upon adding in the correct server info, was able to sync all of my content.  FDroid OC 1.7.0 copy - https://f-droid.org/repo/com.owncloud.android_10700000.apk

I then uninstalled 1.7.0, and reinstalled 1.7.1 from the Play Store, and while it could connect to my server, it was again unable to sync my files, and the entire file listing is now empty.


Device:  Google Nexus 5
OS Version: 4.4.4 stock (not rooted)
OC Server: 6.0.2 on QNAP, unknown PHP version
title: 1.7.1 broke sync
Hotfix user_agent

#### Steps
1. Upload file "test.txt" directly to server
2. Open Android client
3. Pick "Keep in sync" for that file and wait for download
4. Go offline (airplane mode)
5. In the web UI, change "test.txt" and save
6 On mobile (still offline), edit "test.txt" too and save
7. Go back online
8. Long press on "test.txt" and pick "Refresh file"

At this point you get a dialog that says:
"Remote file "test.txt" is not synchronized with local file. Continuing will replace content of file on server" with three buttons: "Don't upload", "Keep both" and "Overwrite".

I want to overwrite the local file, so should I pick "Don't upload" or "Overwrite" ? Does "Overwrite" mean "Overwrite server file" or "Overwrite local file" ?

Also the dialog mentions "continuing" but there is no "continue" button.

body:
Android client does not respect the same protocol as the desktop client for chunked uploads.

For chunked PUT the client should send the OC-Total-Length header specifying the total file size (like the desktop sync client does). This gives a server a possibility, for example, to check the final file size as an integrity check. You may check with @dragotin and @DeepDiver1975 for details.

BWT, we started drafting the spec. It is not yet finalized: https://github.com/cernbox/smashbox/blob/master/protocol/protocol.md

You may also check if issues with failing 1MB+ uploads (e.g. https://github.com/owncloud/android/issues/402) are not related.
title: android chunked upload: missing OC-Total-Length header

body:
ownCloud for Android stores the local copy of the files in public storage. That allows that other apps in the device may access the downloaded files with no other special permission than access to the file system. The advantage of this approach is providing an extra way to share files with other apps. The drawback is that other apps may modify the files of the account with no barrier or control from the ownCloud app, what may result in security issues,

We are planning to start using private storage instead. The lack of access though the file system will be a limitation for regular file browsers, but there are still other means to get access to the ownCloud files from other apps. Besides, we should also implement the DocumentProvider API to provide the newest and safer. 

Our main concern about this change is how the current users will receive it. We'd like to read opinions here to get an idea.

How would you see that the app directly moves the current ownCloud folder to private storage? Would you prefer it as an optional setting, or as a mandatory option?

cc @jancborchardt @MTRichards @rperezb @tobiasKaminsky @LukeOwncloud @MMMarcy @Stoyicker and any other who wants to join the discussion.
title: About private Vs public storage

The new grid view in 1.7.0 might be a great feature if you are able to select it like gallery in the owncloud web-app.
But it should not be the forced AND ONLY view in a file-client like the android app.

Further more this view is forced automatic active in all folders with only pictures in it and mostly only shows "placeholders" for the pics (on a Owncloud 7.x Server) and no additional filenames.

But even if the previews will work, a gallery style view should be an ADDITIONAL option and not the only possibility to view this type of files in a list and to decide, if you want to download the whole file on your android.

body:
Hello, I'm doing research on Android async programming. Some articles (for example [this article](http://bon-app-etit.blogspot.com/2013/04/the-dark-side-of-asynctask.html)) mention that AsyncTask leads to memory leak and losing task result when there's a configuration change (such as orientation change). Android docs recommend [AsyncTaskLoader](http://developer.android.com/reference/android/content/AsyncTaskLoader.html), which avoid the problems in AsyncTask.

I try to replace one AsyncTask with AsyncTaskLoader in `owncloud` in this pr (you don't have to merge). Do you think AsyncTaskLoader will work better for `owncloud`? Do you want to replace all AsyncTask to AsyncTaskLoader?
title: replace AsyncTask to AsyncTaskLoader

body:
SabreDAV only allows these properties to be returned:
https://github.com/fruux/sabre-dav/blob/master/lib/DAV/PropFind.php#L50

In past OC versions we hacked Sabre to also include "oc:permissions", "oc:size", etc.

We are now upgrading to Sabre 2.1 (https://github.com/owncloud/core/issues/12876) and would like to remove the hack (which is actually not possible to use any more due to code changes in SabreDAV).

Please update the mobile client to explicitly request the properties.
A PROPFIND request could send a body that looks like this:
```
<?xml version="1.0"?>
<a:propfind xmlns:a="DAV:" xmlns:oc="http://owncloud.org/ns">
<a:prop><a:getcontenttype/></a:prop>
<a:prop><a:getetag/></a:prop>
<a:prop><oc:permissions/></a:prop>
<a:prop><oc:size/></a:prop>
...
</a:propfind>
```

As an added bonus: note that if you only want the mtime, then just request "a:getlastmodified". This way the server doesn't need to do extra work for properties that you don't want :smile: 

CC @davivel as discussed
title: Send requested properties in PROPFIND, do not use allprops
Cancel transfer for deleted users

body:
Hi, I am using the ownCloud Android App version 1.6.2 and I would like to know if you could include support for EC-based ciphers, I am particularly interested in stop supporting SHA1. See closed issue for mirall (https://github.com/owncloud/client/issues/764) implemented in 1.7.1.

I am running apache and I have the following directives:

SSLProtocol All -SSLv2 -SSLv3
SSLCipherSuite ECDH+AESGCM:DH+AESGCM:ECDH+AES+SHA384:ECDH+AES+SHA256:DH+AES:!RSA+AES256:!ADH:!AECDH:!MD5:!DSS:!aNULL:!eNULL:!LOW:!EXP
SSLHonorCipherOrder on

These directives allow you to use cyphers that support forward secrecy and work with a wide range of clients. In my apache log using Android-ownCloud 1.6.2 I get:

[15/Jan/2015:12:18:46 -0500] 192.168.1.16 - TLSv1.2 DHE-RSA-AES256-SHA

However, I would like to avoid using SHA1, and when I include the following directive in the SSLCipherSuite :!SHA1 the Android-ownCloud stops working.

This is a paid app and the new ciphers have been implemented in the Windows and Mac clients for sure. I would greatly appreciate it if you could update the Android-ownCloud as well.
title: Update OpenSSL to provide EC-based ciphers

body:
That would be awesome. At the moment I cannot put a picture from owncloud inside a gallery on my android.

Android supports multiple galleries so I think why not have a feature to make any picture folder from owncloud appear in the android gallery?

This will make it much easier to integrate pictures into apps, i.E. setting a wallpaper for the texting (SMS) app.
title: Share a picture folder inside the phone gallery
Fix. Avoid load logs again when changing device orientation

body:
I copied the content of one OC server to another. The desktop sync client works with the new OC server. But after deleting the old OC account from OwnCloud App (1.6.2) and adding the new one, I am now stuck in an endless loading loop (for about 2 hrs now). Although there were some connections to the server at the beginning of that loading loop, there is now no opened connection to the server.

Reinstallation of the app, deleting app cache as well as owncloud folders on sd card did not help.

Now when I delete that new account and add an account for the old OC server (which worked before), it also seems to endlessly load.

The OC server is running stable version 7.0.3. It contains about 9800 files with a size of around 16 GB in that specific account. There are no specific errors or warnings logged on the server.

EDIT: Just tested with an empty test account and it's the same.
title: Endless loading after deleting old OC account and adding new one
Copy files

body:
Why does owncloud app come with a media player for audio and video? 
It would make sense if media was streamed. But currently it is downloaded and then played. These files can be played with any player, cf. https://github.com/owncloud/android/issues/775

Making a good movie player is out of scope for the owncloud app which is supposed to sync files. 

Currently the movie player does not work well: Movie starts over when turning device, when clicking on movie error is shown and movie stops, white background is annoying, no full screen, ...

I propose to drop the movie player (which is the same as the audio player?).
title: Drop movie and audio player. Focus on important matters.

Other Funktion Wish:

More Data Syn Funktions. Not only auto upload Videos and pictures.

body: This will make ownCloud fit in more with the rest of the platform.
title: Use the native Android folder icon

body:
This screen:

![Screenshot of ownCloud app on a tablet in landscape orientation, showing a folder view with many images](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/911174/5236973/dacb4a78-7815-11e4-8e1c-d969e1133112.png)

has a lot of open space to the right. Context from other apps implies that the behavior here will be that selecting something in the left pane will open a preview on the right, but instead what happens is that the image is opened full-screen.

Instead, a preview should be shown in the right pane and if tapped, then the image should be opened full-screen as we currently do it.
title: Show previews in the right pane of tablet landscape mode

owncloud/android#661 got merged too quickly after owncloud/android-library#38 so we did not have time to update the submodule to point to the organization repository.

Please note that this is pointing to develop because Gradle cannot use a submodule which does not support Gradle, and develop is the branch that supports it right now.

body:
### Steps to reproduce
1. Select to download an mp3
2. Go to a music app
3. App realizes that there is a new audio
4. In own cloud app, rename or move the audio
5. App doesn’t realize that the audio has been renamed. When you click on it, it’s not possible to reproduce it. The new one should appear in the music app.

### Expected behaviour
App realizes that the audio has change its name, and it is shown in the music app.

### Actual behaviour
App doesn’t realize that the audio has been renamed. When you click on it, it’s not possible to reproduce it. 

### Device
Android 4.1.2
title: MediScanner isn’t trigger after renaming/moving files

body:
### Steps to reproduce
1. Select to download an mp3
2. Go to a music app
3. App realizes that there is a new audio
4. In own cloud app, delete the audio locally or remote
5. App doesn’t realize that the audio is not there anymore. When you click on it, it’s not possible to reproduce it

### Expected behaviour
App realizes that the audio is not there anymore.

### Actual behaviour
App doesn’t realize that the audio is not there anymore. When you click on it, it’s not possible to reproduce it

### Device
Android 4.1.2
title: MediScanner isn’t trigger after deleting files

### Expected behaviour
I have two Android devices: One with an existing configuration and a second one where I try to set up the owncloud client first time after fresh install.

### Actual behaviour
1.
On the first one, files list will not be updated anymore even if I refresh. Sync doesn't work either. Error message is "sync issues, please try again later". It used to work until recently but unfortunately I cannot specify a date when it stopped working.

2.
On the new device, I cannot login. After entering the correct credentials, I see the message "empty here, please upload something" (or something similar, mine is German) followed by the notification that I should login again with the correct credentials.

Credentials are 100% right. They are working for the Linux sync client and for web login. I verified what I entered with the uncovering eye. Linux sync client is working at the same time when the Android client is not working properly.

Please note:
- The password contains an exclamation mark.
- All tests performed via Wifi.
- I tried with latest stable Owncloud 7.0.3 but suspected an issue with the new release and rolled back to my backed up 7.0.2.
- EDIT: I changed the password to letters and digits only but to no avail.

### Steps to reproduce
Old device:

1. Open owncloud client.
2. Browse directory structure.
3. Refresh and still see outdated content.

New device:

1. Enter the correct credentials.

### Environment data
Android version:
Old device: 4.3
New device: 4.2.2

Device model: 
Old device: Samsung Galaxy S3
New device: Samsung Galaxy Tab 10.1N Wifi

Stock or customized system:
Old device: stock
New device: latest CM 10.1 nightly build 

ownCloud app version:
both 1.6.1

ownCloud server version:
I tried 7.0.3 and restored a backup from 7.0.2

body:
This issue is meant to discuss improvements in the Android Client. I posted a [workaround](https://github.com/owncloud/android/issues/340#issuecomment-61554681) before, little bit like a wake up call to that many users request one thing, but nothing happens.

This is purely a discussion, and nothing else. It´s not personal against anyone either. I just want to make it clear what is missing, and what would improve the client - a lot. PR´s are more than welcome.

As I see it today we are missing or could improve:
- [ ] Photos and videos gets downloaded and is stored both in the regular photos folder of the phone in DCIM, and also by ownCloud client in "Misc". #588 #592 #640 #601 #346 #156 #375 
- [ ] When a photo or video is taken and fails, it should retry again. #340 #646  
- [ ] Add a delay for Instant Uploads so you have time to delete the photos you don´t want before they get uploaded to the server. #643 
- [ ] A "smart upload" that get´s information from server and don´t upload it if there already is a copy, or upload it once more and overwrite the old file, or make a new copy, and *only* one copy in that case. #554 
- [ ] Only upload when phone is charging. #465 
- [ ] Two-way sync. #3 
- [ ] Browse the pictures without downloading them, instead - get the information from the server directly. #588 
- [ ] Delete the picture from phone (DCIM folder) after it have successfully been uploaded. #588 

*This is what my workaround fixes. But it should not have to be a workaround, it should be native, in the original ownCloud app.* 

**New suggestions:**
- [ ] Download a folder - this is quite nice as people might have 100 mp3s in one folder for example. (Thanks @wakeup)
- [ ] ______________


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Questions to begin with:
- Why haven´t this been prioritized before?
- What obstacles is present to make this happen?
- Why is this bad ideas design-wise?
- Why is so many users not being listened to?

My intentions are good, and have always been. I spend 95% of my free time on/with ownCloud, of course I want to make it better but right now it feels like there are many different ways to deal (or not deal) with these issues. Could we please talk it through?

CCing all that could be interested in this: @jancborchardt @davivel @LukeOwncloud @stefan-niedermann @tobiasKaminsky @owncloud/designers
title: What could be improved or added as a new feature to make Android client better?

body:
The protocol activity allows to send the log via mail (cf. LogHistoryActivity.java). However, it explicitly uses Gmail. Source code looks like this: 

    // Explicitly only use Gmail to send
    intent.setClassName("com.google.android.gm","com.google.android.gm.ComposeActivityGmail");

Why should owncloud do that? There are other mail clients around, which people use. And even worse, if Gmail is not available, owncloud crashes:

    10-29 07:54:24.445: I/ActivityManager(31009): START u0 {act=android.intent.action.SEND_MULTIPLE typ=text/plain flg=0x10000001 cmp=com.google.android.gm/.ComposeActivityGmail (has clip) (has extras)} from pid 32649
    10-29 07:54:24.445: E/AndroidRuntime(32649): FATAL EXCEPTION: main
    10-29 07:54:24.445: E/AndroidRuntime(32649): android.content.ActivityNotFoundException: Unable to find explicit activity class {com.google.android.gm/com.google.android.gm.ComposeActivityGmail}; have you declared this activity in your AndroidManifest.xml?
    10-29 07:54:24.445: E/AndroidRuntime(32649): 	at android.app.Instrumentation.checkStartActivityResult(Instrumentation.java:1618)
    10-29 07:54:24.445: E/AndroidRuntime(32649): 	at android.app.Instrumentation.execStartActivity(Instrumentation.java:1417)
    10-29 07:54:24.445: E/AndroidRuntime(32649): 	at android.app.Activity.startActivityForResult(Activity.java:3370)
    10-29 07:54:24.445: E/AndroidRuntime(32649): 	at android.app.Activity.startActivityForResult(Activity.java:3331)
    10-29 07:54:24.445: E/AndroidRuntime(32649): 	at android.support.v4.app.FragmentActivity.startActivityForResult(FragmentActivity.java:840)
    10-29 07:54:24.445: E/AndroidRuntime(32649): 	at android.app.Activity.startActivity(Activity.java:3566)
    10-29 07:54:24.445: E/AndroidRuntime(32649): 	at android.app.Activity.startActivity(Activity.java:3534)
    10-29 07:54:24.445: E/AndroidRuntime(32649): 	at com.owncloud.android.ui.activity.LogHistoryActivity.sendMail(LogHistoryActivity.java:161)
    10-29 07:54:24.445: E/AndroidRuntime(32649): 	....


I would use Android's chooser to let the user choose which mail app to use (if there is no default). If no one objects, I'd issue a PR. @davivel @jancborchardt 

PS: The send mail option is still in develop branch only.

Due to the recent poodle exploit I disabled SSLv3 in my apache configuration. Unfortunately after that uploading files doesn't work anymore with the OC Android client.

**Steps to reproduce:**

Having these lines in the apache virtual host configuration works:

    SSLCipherSuite ECDH+AESGCM:DH+AESGCM:ECDH+AES256:DH+AES256:ECDH+AES128:DH+AES:ECDH+3DES:DH+3DES:RSA+AESGCM:RSA+AES:RSA+3DES:!aNULL:!MD5:!DSS
    SSLCipherSuite ALL:!ADH:!EXPORT56:!RC4+RSA:+HIGH:-MEDIUM:+EXP:+eNULL:-SSLv2:SSLv3

Disabling SSLv3 like this will not work:

    SSLCipherSuite ECDH+AESGCM:DH+AESGCM:ECDH+AES256:DH+AES256:ECDH+AES128:DH+AES:ECDH+3DES:DH+3DES:RSA+AESGCM:RSA+AES:RSA+3DES:!aNULL:!MD5:!DSS
    SSLCipherSuite ALL:!ADH:!EXPORT56:!RC4+RSA:+HIGH:-MEDIUM:+EXP:+eNULL:-SSLv2:-SSLv3

**My Environment**

Apache:

      apache2 -version
      Server version: Apache/2.2.22 (Debian)
      Server built:   Jul 24 2014 15:34:00

Android with cyanogenmod 10.1.3-n7000 on a Samsung Galaxy Note
OC Android client 1.5.8
title: Upload not possible when SSLv3 is disabled

body:
Hi,
So, this is a draft implementation for #649. It's not fully tested yet, as it still have at least an issue (about which I have a question, hence this pull request.

I'm using `[Images|Video].Media.DATE_TAKEN` to allow the user to rename the file depending on the date the photo or video was taken. It's working fine when the device is online at the time the media is taken, but not when the device is offline and the media uploaded later.

In this specific case, `InstantUploadBroadcastReceiver.handleConnectivityAction` manages the uploading of the file which has not been sent yet. However, at that time, we only have the (local) file path. The mime type was needed here, but instead of using the media store to retrieve it, a simple map lookup with the file extension is made. Is there any reason to this, excepted the fact it's simpler for the mime type only? I'll need to use the media store here to be able to fetch the date the media was taken, I think. I don't really see any other way.

Thanks
title: Instant upload: rename files on upload

We have added Gradle support, following Google guidelines. We have also simplified the procedure and updated the setup instructions.

It should be mentioned that in order to be able to build with Gradle the library must support Gradle as well, so we have changed where the submodule points to to our fork until owncloud/android-library#38 gets merged, as indicated on #625.

body:
I am using the android client (v.1.5.8 from f-droid) on a Samsung Note 8 (android v. 4.2.2) and I am trying to keep some pdf files in sync. Since I tick on the "Keep file up to date" option for every file, I expect files to automatically syncronize to the server after I add annotations or highlights, i.e. files should be uploaded soon after they are modified. However, this does not happen, not even if I force a sync tapping on "Refresh account". When I check the modification time of the pdfs using a file browser, I can see the modification time is older than the one shown in the client.

The only workaround I found is
(1) to manually force a sync by long tapping the file and then choosing "Refresh file"
or
(2) to force the sync of *another* file in the same folder as in (1), then the other files are uploaded after I modified them (this seems to work consistently, at least as far as I could test)

I don't have similar problems with other types of files, for instance text files are uploaded immediately after modification. Also there is nothing suspicious in owncloud.log on the server.
title: Client does not always upload pdf files upon modification

body:
The whole point behind using Instant Upload is that I never have to worry about manually synchronizing my pictures and videos up to ownCloud.

Sometimes a network connection is unavailable, or the client can't contact the server for some reason, and the upload fails -- and then it stops trying and just tells me that it failed. Then I have to remember that something failed, and then manually compare what's in ownCloud and what's in my camera folder, and go through the exact painful process that Instant Upload is supposed to be preventing.

Instant Upload should *never* stop trying unless I tell it to skip a particular file. Otherwise, every time it gets a chance, it should try, try again (this is what, as far as I can tell, at least Google+ does, and various other applications as well). The current behavior makes this feature unreliable, or in other words, *not useful*.
title: When Instant Upload fails, it stops trying. This should never happen.

I just changed the password of my ownCloud account.

After that, on my android device, I tried changing the password for the ownCloud account. That seemed to be easy enough, and my new password was accepted without problems. After that, however, the ownCloud android client was constantly complaining about a "failed synchronisation" for the instant upload images. Also when navigating inside the owncloud app, even though some folder content was shown, it seemed to be outdated, as of most folders the subfolders (especially those I had never loaded before) were empty, and the spinner on the top never stopped turning (even for the folders where some content was shown).

Is there any log to check for the case when such problems happen?

I tried setting the password multiple times, I'm sure it was the correct one, it never worked

I then tried removing the account and recreating it, which also didn't change anything.

Next I tried "force stopping" the app and removing all its data, which also didn't help.

At last, I tried uninstalling and reinstalling the client (and the JellyBean workaround app, which still seems to be required on 4.4, correct?), and after recreating the account then, it finally worked again.

Anybody else seen this? Any log or so I can check for details as to why the simple password change procedure didn't work in my case?

Note: I didn't specifically check the version before reinstalling, but since automatic upgrades are enabled, I suppose it was the version 1.5.8 of the app before and after re-installation.

I'm currently trying a second password change to see if this behavior is reproducible in my environment. Edit: Not reproducible at the moment. So I'm closing this issue. Maybe it will be a guidance for others having a similar experience...

### Steps to reproduce
1. Install oc-android (v1.5.8)
2. Try to add a Server which only supports TLSv1.2 Ciphers

### Expected behaviour
Android 4.4.* supports TLSv1.2 so it should work with the following ciphers:

TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384
TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256
TLS_DHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384
TLS_DHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256
TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_CBC_SHA384
TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_CBC_SHA
TLS_DHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_CBC_SHA256
TLS_DHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_CBC_SHA
TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_CBC_SHA256
TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_CBC_SHA
TLS_DHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_CBC_SHA256
TLS_DHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_CBC_SHA

### Actual behaviour
SSL-Initialisation fails

### Server configuration
**Operating system**: Centos 6.5

**Web server:** nginx 1.7.5

**Database:** mysql

**PHP version:** 5.3.3

**ownCloud version:** 7.0.2

Considering that Google is putting a lot of effort in Android Studio we ( https://github.com/owncloudChalmers/ ) think that introducing the Gradle build system is necessary, both for the android-library repository and this one.

We are already experimenting with it for the library ( https://github.com/owncloudChalmers/android-library buildsystem/gradle_develop, conversion of develop) and are really close to complete it (basically only lacking the Travis CI configuration files). We can also take responsibility for porting the build system for the app repository as well.

It should be mentioned that the default Gradle project structure differs from the Ant one, so switching to it will break compatibility with Ant. However, we believe this is a necessary change.
title: Switch to Gradle

body:
When I enter the owncloud URL with a trailing slash:
https://192.168.0.3/owncloud/
I get an "unknown error" message when hitting the enter button.

The Apache2 access log was showing the following entries:
192.168.0.246 - - [01/Sep/2014:20:35:21 +0000] "GET /owncloud//status.php HTTP/1.1" 200 773 "-" "Android-ownCloud"
192.168.0.246 - - [01/Sep/2014:20:35:21 +0000] "HEAD /owncloud//remote.php/webdav/ HTTP/1.1" 403 681 "-" "Android-ownCloud"

You could see that the HEAD request gets a 403 Forbidden response and the context path was showing a double slash "owncloud//status.php".

After removing the trailing slash the error message went away. The Android App should strip the trailing slash so that the user does not get confused by this kind of error.
title: Create account page shows "unknown error" when adding URL with trailing slash

body: Just experienced an issue with the app when an instant upload of an image (and possibly a video too) is being uploaded with Antivirus enabled on the server end of Owncloud. It appears that the upload is successful and the file is indeed uploaded, but since ClamAv (Clamscan) is scanning the file which might take a while on slow systems, the android app says it has failed. This is probably a timeout issue in my opinion.
title: Upload failed when server scanning via clamscan

body:
### Expected behavior
File is uploaded or an error message is displayed.

### Actual behavior
When using Google Photos app share function, it often does nothing and sometimes the owncloud app just crashes. Uploading the same file, using the share button, from Sony Album app or file commander, owncloud always works. Once it did start working, but failed once the apps had been restarted.

### Steps to reproduce
1. Launch Google Photos app
2. Select an image, press the share icon and select Owncloud
3. press upload
4. nothing happens, no errors, no network activity, no activity in apache logs.
5. Recent apps show owncloud, and when pressed "The application could not be started" message appears and owncloud closes
6. Repeat with Sony Album app or File Commander and uploading works every time.

### Environment data
Android version: 4.4.2
Google Photos 4.4.3.69327628
ownCloud app version: 1.5.7
title: Sharing from photos app causes a crash

body:
This is more of a feature than an issue, but it could be of some relevance to the automatic photo/video uploader. 

There needs to be a way where we can select a local directory and a remote directroy so that they can be synced either both ways, or just to the remote/local folder (a bit like FolderSync) since if the app wasn't running, then not all my photos/videos would be uploaded and since the app doesn't search for any new media, then they won't be uploaded to the server.

It'd be great if this was up in the high priority list, but I know that there may be higher priorities already queued up.
title: Sync Local File Directory AND Remote Directory together

body:
### Expected behaviour
When I connect to an unsecured (HTTP) owncloud server, the app should net tell me that there is a secure connection.

### Actual behaviour
I have bought NO (!) SSL certificate on my account at All-inkl.com, but when I enter the server & credentials into the owncloud android app (without http(s), the app figures this out autimatically, the app asks me that the certificate cannot be trusted, because of a not-fitting cert. If I accept this, the app tells me that I now have a secure connection.

### Steps to reproduce
I have added a test user so that you can test your connection.
1. open the android app and add a new owncloud account, use <removed> as server. After entering the server, (before username/pw) the app directly tries to connect to this server.
2. The app tells you that there is a wrong certificate (it is using the generic cert of All-inkl for *.kasserver.com - this seems to be weird routing, but anyway - accept the certificate.
I think that all-inkl then redirects you to the HTTP version of the site silently.
3. The OC app tells you now that there is a secure connection, which is frankly impossible.

Just try <removed URL> in your browser, you get the same issue with the cert, if you accept it, you end with http instead of https.
So finally I think the OC app can be tricked into telling me there is a secure connection when there is none.
What astouns me are the logs of "adb logcat" (below).

Actually, the connection and sync works. If you want I can give you a test account on my server.
I think the logs only write out cached URLs as well, and the app, once told that there is HTTPS available, never checks again that the *real* connection (after redirect?) is *really* HTTPS.

### Environment data
Android version: 4.4.4
Device model: Samsung Galaxy S2 (i9100)
Stock or customized system: actual omniROM
ownCloud app version: 1.5.7
ownCloud server version: 7.0.0
### Logs
```
I/ServerNameIndicator( 2954): SNI done, hostname: <removed>
I/GetRemoteStatusOperation( 2954): Connection check at <removed>: Operation finished with HTTP status code -1 (success)
D/GetServerInfoOperation( 2954): Trying empty authorization to detect authentication method
D/RemoteOperationResult( 2954): RemoteOperationResult has processed UNHANDLED_HTTP_CODE: 301
D/ExistenceCheckRemoteOperation( 2954): Existence check for <removed> targeting for  existence finished with HTTP status 301(FAIL)
D/ExistenceCheckRemoteOperation( 2954): Existence check for <removed> targeting for  existence finished with HTTP status 401(FAIL)
D/DetectAuthenticationMethodOperation( 2954): Authentication method found: BASIC_HTTP_AUTH
D/OperationsService( 2954): Called 1 listeners
```
#### Web server error log `not available, hosted.`

#### ownCloud log (data/owncloud.log)
```
could not find that file...
```
title: Display "secure connection" when HTTPS server redirects to HTTP

body:
Hi.
Thank you for a wonderful app.
What I would like added if possible, is the ability to change font size in file lists.
The reason is simple: long filenames get truncated and thus makes it harder to know which file is which, especially in similarly named files.

Adding a "change font size" setting would allow viewing full names without eclipses.

A workaround would be to allow long names spanning multiple rows.
title: Long filenames get truncated

I'm currently using Owncloud and i have a situation for which i did'nt found solution here. 
I'm currently trying to sync a bunch of video files (~6GB for the most of it). I uploaded them without trouble but when i try to sync it from my Server to my windows client, it only download 1.99Gb. I tried to download it from the WebUI and the webdavUI (remote.php/webdav) and got the same issue. 
I changed the file_limit in php.ini to 16GB (as said in documentention) and in the .htaccess.

I have a generic website hosted by godaddy. From there I added a subdomain to point to an ip address such that owncloud6.mydomain.com points to https://192.168.0.1/owncloud6 (that is not the real ip address). The web browser successfully forwards (showing https://192.168.0.1/owncloud6 in the address bar).


### Expected behaviour
The client should be able to handle 301 redirects.

### Actual behaviour

body:
Currently, we show the »shared« indicator right of a file or folder in the list. Especially since the »Shared« folder will be removed, we should make the following enhancements to improve it:
* For folders, use the respective folder icons: [shared with others](https://github.com/owncloud/core/blob/master/core/img/filetypes/folder-shared.png) and [shared via link](https://github.com/owncloud/core/blob/master/core/img/filetypes/folder-public.png) (SVGs in the same folder)

For subfolders or subitems, I would keep them normal for now – not put an indicator on every single file. But if the immediate parent of that file/folder is shared, we should put the shared indicator next to the name of the parent folder in the »Back« button on the top left (for iOS at least).

cc @rperezb @MTRichards
title: Android & iOS: Shared indication
Fixed left details fragment when file is removed

body:
My owncloud server is running in https only on a nginx server and I use server certificates from cacert, cacert root certificates are not included on my android device (and probably in any android). When I installed the owncloud app it was able to connect without problems to the server but I was only able to browse and read the files, any attempt to upload did stalled forever, in the server log I found lots of lines like those:

x.x.x.x - username [04/Apr/2014:20:49:54 +0200] "HEAD /remote.php/webdav/documents/0523acaa096b5e583292145dc8bb77be%20(7).jpg HTTP/1.1" 200 0 "-" "Android-ownCloud"
x.x.x.x - username [04/Apr/2014:20:49:55 +0200] "HEAD /remote.php/webdav/documents/0523acaa096b5e583292145dc8bb77be%20(8).jpg HTTP/1.1" 200 0 "-" "Android-ownCloud"
x.x.x.x - username [04/Apr/2014:20:49:55 +0200] "HEAD /remote.php/webdav/documents/0523acaa096b5e583292145dc8bb77be%20(9).jpg HTTP/1.1" 200 0 "-" "Android-ownCloud"

but nothing was uploaded.

Today I installed CACert's root certificates on my android device and viola, everything works perfectly. I just wanted to let you know since I was not able to find a solution online, maybe others have a similar problem with a server using certificates not issued by a CA trusted by Android.
title: Strange issue with CACert certificates

Currently when I want to upload a file, the dialog shows the hidden files and folders before the other ones. This is very distracting since the hidden files

Four possible solutions:
1. Don’t show hidden folders or files (I don’t think that’s good because you might want to upload them)
2. Have a switch to show hidden files (Might be good, but a bit more work and it would be a prominent switch.)
3. Sort hidden files and folders after normal files and folders (Not very elegant and just shifts the problem)
4. Sort hdiden files and folders among normal files and folders, alphabetically. Basically just omit the dot when sorting.

I think option 4 is the most elegant and easy one. What do you think @rperezb @davivel?
title: Upload file dialog: hidden files/folders are shown first

body:
I use the latest ownCloud Android App (1.5.4).

Today I discovered that the battery of my mobile phone discharged quite fast. After looking at the battery settings I saw that 55% of the battery power was used by the ownCloud client. I disabled the android client for the rest of the day and enabled it at the evening again. Immediately it starts to connect to the ownCloud server again and starts loading.

I looked at the access.log of the ownCloud server and discovered that the android clients sends a lot of requests to the server, like:

```
178.10.26.92 - schiesbn [26/Feb/2014:19:51:12 +0100] "GET /ocs/v1.php/apps/files_sharing/api/v1/shares?path=%2Fpresentationen%2F&reshares=false&subfiles=true HTTP/1.1" 200 1020 "-" "Android-ownCloud"
```

It seems that it sends this request for every single file in my ownCloud. This can take really long and consume a lot of battery power for users with a lot of files.

I wonder why we don't send this requests only on demand for the files/folder we need the information?

Edit: After a few hours I even see repeated requests in my log, it seems that there is an endless loop sending this API calls.
title: to many OCS Share API calls (endless loop)
Remove folder size info

body:
### Steps to reproduce
1. Web: login to ownCloud server
2. Web: Create a folder "to delete" on the server
3. Web: Create a text file "test.txt" inside and write some contents in it
4. Android Client: Refresh the account to trigger sync
5. Android Client: navigate into "to delete" and download the "test.txt"
6. Android File Manager: navigate to the account's folder, see that "to delete" exists
7. Web: Delete folder "to delete"
8. Android Client: refresh the account and see that "to delete" disappeared from the ownCloud app
9. Android File Manager: Using a file manager, navigate to the account's folder

### Expected result
"to delete" folder is gone from the mobile device's filesystem

### Actual result
"to delete" folder still exists and so does "test.txt".
If that file was huge it would waste the mobile device's space without the user knowing.

### Versions
Android app: 1.5.3
OC server: 6.0.1
File Manager: Ghost Commander
title: Delete already synced folder from server, still exists on client

body:
(Opening a separate specific issue since https://github.com/owncloud/android/issues/58 is riddled with discussion already.)

[DAVdroid](http://davdroid.bitfire.at/) is an [open source](https://github.com/rfc2822/davdroid) Android app for synchronizing Calendars and Contacts via CalDAV and CardDAV.

Currently you need to install it separately and add your ownCloud account yet again. Since the default calendar and contacts management are used anyway and this app just adds a backend and syncing – can’t we just integrate it?

Like, just have a switch in the settings for syncing Calendar and Contacts. It will be a much much smoother experience on mobile. Not needing to fiddle with the addresses and the setup too much.

(Also cc @DeepDiver1975)
title: Possibility of integrating DAVdroid

body:
As you know we generate »filename (2)« for duplicates. Currently sorting goes like this:

* filename (2)
* filename (3)
* filename

Which makes it pretty confusing since the original document is all the way on the bottom. Instead it should go like this:

* filename
* filename (2)
* filename (3)


Even worse, when you have numbers in parentheses which exceed 10, it sorts like this:

* filename (18)
* filename (19)
* filename (2)
* filename (20)
* filename (21)
title: Sorting is off for filenames with (2) numbers in parentheses

Our ownCloud account(s) password(s) is(/are) stored in plaintext under the "password" column, into the database file:

/data/system/account.db

Wouldn't it be - for example - possible to at least obfuscate it in order to have it a bit more protected ?
Even though we should not, you know that many of us have rooted phones, and it could be a (slight) security plus for our ownCloud account(s) security not to store them as pure plaintext ... don't you think so ?

- Owncloud Android Client version: 1.5.2
- Android version: 2.3.7 (rooted)
title: SECURITY: Accounts passwords stored in plaintext

body:
After enabling the InstantUpload feature, all photo files seem to be duplicated by the client - they exist once in their original location in the DCIM folder, and once in the /owncloud/user@ochost/(Instant|Sofort)Upload folder.
This seems redundant to me - I don't see any use in having those duplicate files? The only thing I can think of which such a copy could achieve would be marking which files are successfully uploaded? But there surely is a simpler way of doing that than to just copy the file? Maybe store a file with the same name as the image plus e.g. .hash suffix, containing a hash of the uploaded file?
Those copies just wastes a lot of space on my (non-extensible) internal storage.

Using the latest version available in Market (1.4.3).
Server version is 6.0.1 (but is going on since 5.0.13 at least).
title: InstantUpload files duplicated in ownCloud folder

### Actual behaviour
Login credentials get forgotten and I need to re-enter them once the app is started again (i.e. when the app is not running on Android).

I've also noticed this happening with an older version of the app (about a year ago) with ownCloud server version 4.

Another user reported the same issue at an ownCloud forum: http://forum.owncloud.org/viewtopic.php?f=24&t=19283

body:
### Expected behaviour

On same wifi as owncloud server, I expect uploads to happen fast without issue. If it does fail for whatever issue, I expect it to recognize it fast.

### Actual behaviour

Doesn't happen all the time, but sometimes the upload fails or even stalls. I think the uploads also seem slow for being on the same wifi as the server, but I can't really say for sure.
What do I mean by stall? While uploading a 25 megs file, the notification bar says it has been at 38% for atleast a confirmed 1 hour, with no sign of moving or registering as a fail. When I click the notification icon, it opens up the file view, but shows no progress bar at all. The file isn't visible on the server through normal web view. As best I can tell there is no way to cancel this upload either.
The destination folder wasn't a shared folder, just a normal one.

![screenshot_2013-12-29-12-18-03](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/5427943/1819776/eb11b13c-70b0-11e3-803c-33785382196e.png)
![screenshot_2013-12-29-12-14-42](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/5427943/1819775/eb0e7fee-70b0-11e3-9dab-567d47d4fb43.png)

### Steps to reproduce

1. Upload multiple files (above 2 megs, sometimes around 20 megs).
I was uploading through the share within ROM Toolbox trying to backup all my apps. But I have had this happen with share within Gallery too with multiple files.
2. Rinse and repeat until it happens.

It doesn't happen all the time, I was able to upload probably 300 megs until one file stalled.

### Environment data
Android version: 4.1.2

Device model: Droid Bionic

Stock or customized system: rooted stock

ownCloud app version:1.5.2

ownCloud server version: 6.0.0a (stable) 

### Logs
#### Web server error log

The date this happened is 12/29. The log wasn't set to everything until after the event, so basically nothing was shown in the log on the issue. The server log was set to whatever is default with the installation.

Debug 	OC\Files\Cache\Scanner 	!!! No reuse of etag for 'cache' !!! cache: Array ( [fileid] => 113 [storage] => home::ricky [path] => cache [parent] => 1 [name] => cache [mimetype] => httpd/unix-directory [mimepart] => httpd [size] => 307996384 [mtime] => 1387989356 [storage_mtime] => 1387989356 [encrypted] => [unencrypted_size] => 0 [etag] => 52bb172d29f2c ) data: Array ( [mimetype] => httpd/unix-directory [mtime] => 1388335368 [size] => -1 [etag] => 52c0577333d6c [storage_mtime] => 1388335368 ) 	2013-12-29T17:10:11+00:00
Warning 	PHP 	Invalid argument supplied for foreach() at /media/hd1/www/owncloud/apps/files_versions/lib/versions.php#519 	2013-12-25T18:12:05+00:00
Warning 	PHP 	Undefined index: all at /media/hd1/www/owncloud/apps/files_versions/lib/versions.php#477 	2013-12-25T18:12:05+00:00

#### ownCloud log (data/owncloud.log)

Unfortunately I tried doing a search with ASTRO File Manager, and I was unable to find any "owncloud.log" files located internally or on the sd card.
title: Upload Issues

body:
### Expected behaviour
Files added or removed from root folder should appear or disappear from Android client when the client is refreshed.

### Actual behaviour
Files appear correctly after the first login.  After that, files in the root folder do not change to match changes made on the server.  If a file is added, removed or renamed it will remain the same in the Android client.  Refresh, reboot and app relaunch don't help.  Resetting the app data or reinstalling the app does cause the contents to refresh once (after logging in again).

Folders work normally.  Files inside folders work normally.  The problem is only with files in the root folder.

### Steps to reproduce
1. Install Android app
2. Login and note files in root folder are correct
3. Change a file (add, delete or rename) using the web interface or sync client.
4. Refresh the Android app and note that files in the root folder do not change

### Environment data
Android version: 4.3 and 4.2.2

Device model: Galaxy Nexus and Nexus 7

body:
I use Titanium backup to make backups of all my apps.  Now, I'm very anal retentive and want to back these up to my ownCloud instance, so I set Titanium to back up to a folder under ownCloud.  However, the only way to get it to sync is to 'upload' each file manually, which is time consuming.  Yes, I can do it 'once' and then it will sync changes, but if I install a new app I have to remember to do this.

I think a feature that'd be useful, would be to set up a folder on my Android and allow that to sync any changes and upload folders/files automatically.
title: Upload Files From Folder

Hi,

I have been using owncloud to sync Linux, Windows and Android devices for a while already. I placed the files to sync on the clients in a "clientsync" folder.

Is there a way to sync only the remote "clientsync" folder like it was in the past?

Very nice work!

3 thoughts:

1) The update procedure seems to be called even when there is no Internet connection (at least the update circle is shown for a moment before it disappears). This does not happen when manually initiating a "refresh account". Is there a check for Internet connectivity? Can it also be used to this "refresh_folder_contents_when_browsed_into" feature?

2) Folders are refreshed when browsed into. But also when coming out. It that necessary? When you step down the folder hierarchy, you usually just stepped up moments before, didn't you? So could here bandwidth be saved (for sacrificing a little freshness)?

In the account settings for Android one can merely enable or disable auto syncing.
What is the (default) sync interval?

Are there any plans to extend this option?
I did not find anything in here: https://github.com/owncloud/design/tree/master/mobile

body:
Consider the following use case: I use my device as an offline  reader for PDFs that I find throughout the day on my desktop. When I find a document that I want to read later, I copy it to an ownCloud-shared folder. When I get to my Android device, I want all files collected during the day to be available on it, even in offline mode. 

Currently I have to perform the following tiresome sequence on the device:
1. Press "Update" and wait until finishes
2. Open the folder used to store new documents
3. Click on each of the documents so that  it gets downloaded and opened in a PDF viewer
4. Close the viewer and proceed to the next file.

When there are more than a couple of new files this sequence becomes a really boring thing to do.

What I want to suggest is that certain folders can be marked as auto-update, just  like it can be done for individual files today. The above scenario becomes much more simple:
0. Mark a folder as "auto-update" (once)
1. Press "Update" and wait until all new files are downloaded to the device.
title: Enhancement: allow folders to be synchronized automatically.

Then when it finally shows the file list, every action (clicking on any folder, clicking the back button, or even just clicking on the settings button or trying to save them) sometimes (every second time or so) takes about 10 seconds... frequently also the popup "App is not reacting. Do you want to close it?" pops up. I have no files which I keep "up to date", the synchronisation in the account is disabled, I mainly use ownCloud on the android to access one file, which I infrequently manually download; I do have "Instant Upload" enabled (but that doesn't seem to be fully working either, it doesn't upload all my images, only some of them, but that's another story).

When I'm saying the app is slow, I mean there is no feedback whatsoever if the app is still doing something (let alone what it is doing), the user interface is just stuck; when coming back from settings it sometimes just turns black for a few seconds...
When coming back from the lock screen, I can't even scroll in the file list, I have to wait for a few seconds...

Any more information I could provide to help resolve this? The GN shouldn't be that out of date for the app to run so slow? What could cause this? From my momentary perspective also the battery seems to drain quite fast when the app is running...

Edit: Clearing the App's data didn't change anything. Will try reinstalling next, just to be sure.
Edit 2: Great: After a re-install, it doesn't seem to be able to connect to the account again. It always (first time with the still existing account data, and two more times with the (definitely correctly) entered password) says "invalid credentials".
Edit 3: Removed and recreated the account, restarted the phone, re-tried entering the password several times, but now still just getting an unjustified "Invalid credentials" (the provided credentials are definitely correct). I guess this is basically the worst-case-scenario - going from unusably slow to not usable at all...

Any hints what I could try? I've exhausted all usual methods of resolving Android app problems I could think of!

ownCloud app version: 1.4.1

body:
By tapping the OC icon in the notification pull-down you can trigger an exploit which allows you to browse all your OC content without entering a PIN.  There are many ways to trigger this: during or after an upload, using InstantUpload or manual upload, etc.  Obviously, a prerequisite is that you have activated the app PIN in your settings.

Example:
1. Take a photo in order to trigger InstantUpload.
2. Wait for the OC icon to appear in the notification bar.
3. Pull down the notification bar and tap the icon.  This will display the photo that was just uploaded.
4. Tap "menu" and then "details".  The file details are displayed.
5. Tap the "back" button once.  This will take you to the directory listing (in this case the "InstantUpload" folder).
6. Tap "back" again and you are in your root directory, with full access to all directories, files and app settings.

Step 5 should return to the photo.
Step 6 should return to the home screen.
Whenever directories are accessed, the user should be prompted for the app PIN, if one has been set.

Samsung Galaxy Ace 2 running Android 2.3.6, app 1.4.1 and OC 5.0.7.
title: Exploit: Avoid the PIN prompt by tapping the OC icon in the notification pull-down

body:
The OwnCloud Android app performs pretty poor on large file trees.

FileListListAdapter traverses recursively through all subfolders get the file size of a directory while filling a view in getView().

This results in large database interactions in performance critical sections of the application.

There are two possible solutions to this issue:

* calculate file size of directories on an own Thread.
* calculate file size of directories while syncing and safe directory size to the database.

the latter one should be preferred as it doesn't fuck up the adapter and won't fill up the CPU/RAM/Stack
title: Poor performance on large file trees

To ease and overcome this, I invision to have an app repository in my OC, where all the apps that where bought are residing.
Actually the idea is, that there could be a OC-app serving as "buying agent", that buying agent "installs" the apps into that repository for further use (not as an app that runs in the OC rather an app that will be available for redistribution to be installed on multiple devices,

Than another service app in the OC would act as a "market place" that can be accessed by all mobil devices.
All devices/users with access to the privat OC-bought apps repository, should be able to access the app market (kind of an internal store, where my Mobil devices could install all apps from this "internal store" - to the device.
This is kind of a apps archive and "redistribution" idea for apps in my home mobil device infrastructure.

body:
Currently the file size is shown in different cardinalities. This is very strange when there’s one file »5 MB« and another file »145.98 kB« – the second one seems to be bigger from first sight because it has a bigger number.

Instead, all file sizes should be shown in MB, and exactly one decimal unit (even 5.0 for 5). Differing from the web interface though we should show the »MB« unit after each value though because there is no table heading.

For sizes below 0.1 MB, show »<0.1 MB« – because a file below that size will be downloaded instantly anyway, almost regardless of network. For sizes above 1000 MB, show »>1000 MB«, because a file above that size will take a looong time to download (the exact size and progress should be shown on the download bar screen as feedback).
title: (As an ownCloud Android user I want) file size to be less confusing

### Expected behaviour
Many camera's these days use exif metadata to define whether an image was taken in landscape or portrait mode, yet always store the image in landscape mode.

To properly display such images, the exif data should be parsed for rotation information and this information should be used to apply the proper rotation to the image before displaying it.

### Actual behaviour
I have found the the owncloud client on android ignores the exif rotation information. As a result, images are displayed in the wrong direction. Turning the android device to put the image upright triggers the auto-rotate function resulting in the image being rotated back to its wrong orientation.

### Environment data
Android version: 4.1.1
Device model: Asus Transformer Prime TF201
Stock system, with all official updates applied
ownCloud app version: 1.4.0
ownCloud server version: 4.5

### Logs
Skipped. I don't think this issue requires logs. If you do need them, please tell me which ones to upload.

body:
If you store a lot directories (300 including subdirectories is sufficient), then any sync of the Android client will keep your webserver busy for a few minutes. The apache log shows approximately the following:

x.x.x.x - tom [13/Apr/2013:10:54:17 +0200] "PROPFIND /remote.php/webdav/articles/A/ HTTP/1.1" 207 1425
x.x.x.x - tom [13/Apr/2013:10:54:17 +0200] "PROPFIND /remote.php/webdav/articles/B/ HTTP/1.1" 207 1360
x.x.x.x - tom [13/Apr/2013:10:54:18 +0200] "PROPFIND /remote.php/webdav/articles/C/ HTTP/1.1" 207 945
x.x.x.x - tom [13/Apr/2013:10:54:18 +0200] "PROPFIND /remote.php/webdav/articles/D/ HTTP/1.1" 207 982
x.x.x.x - tom [13/Apr/2013:10:54:19 +0200] "PROPFIND /remote.php/webdav/articles/E/ HTTP/1.1" 207 922

As you can see, each PROPFIND operation can take up to second and every sync triggers a PROPFIND for every directory in the cloud. Consequently the sync takes a few minutes in which the webserver is quite busy. This wastes many resources. 

The iOS client uses a different model: It queries the webserver every time the user changes directory and only asks for the content of the directory the user wants to see. I think this makes a lot more sense than the 'loop through everything' approach. It would be great if this was configurable. My standard use case is: On the laptop, copy a file to owncloud, grab the tablet, read it. On Android I get a five minute wait between the copying and the reading and also my webserver is too busy with basically no-ops.
title: Implement iOS (non-sync) browsing mode.

body:
I set up my ownCloud at home, and immediately went to get the Android app.  It took me about 30 minutes of picture taking to figure out the procedure for getting instant upload to work, and I wanted to suggest that the method by which I had to do it, was perhaps not as obvious as it should be.

Here is how I did it:

1. Create the InstantUpload folder via the web interface in the root "/" of my ownCloud account.
2. Upload a picture to the InstantUpload folder via the web interface.
3. Test a manual upload from my Note to the InstantUpload folder (if you hadn't completed steps 1 and 2, it would fail telling you that the first time you had to be online, which is unfortunately not as clear as it needs to be).
4. Take a picture, and look at your notification shade to see it now uploading automatically.

My suggestion is not to have the instructions come up as a toast notification, but as a true notification that sits in the notification shade.  I had to take a few pictures in a row to be able to even read the whole message.  At that, tapping the notification should bring you to a step by step instructional page outlining how to enable Instant Upload properly.

Now, it is very possible that what I had to do was not the standard way people are getting instant upload to work, but it worked for me - so even if it sits here in the GitHub for someone else to find, so be it.

Thank you for reading.

Jay
title: Galaxy Note - Getting Instant Upload to Work

body:
I have set up an owncloud account with quite some data and folder structure in it. Obviously, syncing that would take some time so it isn't strange that not everything is visible at my phone right at once.

But it seems that the client is trying to sync everything from A-Z and in that order, while I'd think that syncing that what I need the most would be preferable. And what I need the most, are these items that I'm actually looking for. So if I browse into a folder "Work", it can be assumed that I want to see its contents, so syncing the rest should be stopped and the contents of the Work-folder should be shown.

This way, by prioritizing the syncing, the user experience is way more natural, since you don't notice that some folders haven't been synced yet (as you haven't watched in them yet). When you compare owncloud to dropbox (which works this way), there is a significant difference in the time it takes to show a directory.

Actually, thinking about it. On the android client, which behaves a lot like the dropbox client on android right?, the server is 'always right', why would syncing a file list then take so long anyway?
title: Let synchronization be smarter / faster

body:
When downloading music files with the owncloud client, they aren't found in the media player until you plug the phone to a computer (using it as usb memory stick).
The reason is that when the phone is removed from the computer, the "Media Provider" Update event is triggered. This event recognizes changes in the file system and rebuilds the index which then is used by the media player.
This event should also be triggered, when music files were downloaded.

I didn't test it, but the same could apply for pictures and the android gallery app.
title: Trigger Update of Android Media Provider

body:
In spite of what the OC desktop clients do, it would be nice to have a "Keep directory up to date" option for directories, as well as it is available for files now.

The typical use case is a "magic folder" that is always in sync between your desktop, OC and your phone (so that you can work on the files also when you're offline, and as soon as you get back online, your changes are propagated). Another use case is a Music folder to be kept in sync (streaming is not very reliable, and definitely doesn't work when you're offline :-) )

It shouldn't be too hard to implement, as the file synchronizer already seems to be able to handle directories (am I wrong?), and so the only step is to add a long-press feature to directories to enable the synching option.

Another design issue is where to store the data. I believe the user should be able to choose where to mirror the OC directory locally (and the default "/sdcard/owncloud" is used for single-file sync).

Finally, like the desktop clients should do, the first sync should support a "merge" strategy. The use case here is: I have my files already stored on owncloud, and I also copied them to the phone via USB (because it's quicker and cheaper than using my 3G dataplan).

I'm a good Java developer, but new to Android. I'm willing to provide some programming help and all the necessary testing if you're keen on adding this feature.
title: Directory synchronization

It’s weird because in the background the files already start rolling in. If I press »Accept« I am just redirected to where I was before, which is very confusing.

This popup should never show at all, because it’s not helpful and rather the account add screen should be shown then. But apart from this it also seems a bug which wrongly checks on first run if I have an account.

body:
Connecting to SSL secured hosts that require SNI (Server Name Indication) support is currently not possible without accepting all certificates, which is of course undesirable. It would be nice if the owncloud Android client would properly support SNI so hostname based TLS negotiation can be performed, thus securing a valid trust chain and communication.

I've done some research and found a couple of resources indicating that SNI is possible on Android.

http://source-android.frandroid.com/libcore/luni/src/main/java/libcore/net/http/HttpsURLConnectionImpl.java

http://source-android.frandroid.com/libcore/luni/src/main/java/libcore/net/http/HttpConnection.java

http://source-android.frandroid.com/libcore/luni/src/main/java/org/apache/harmony/xnet/provider/jsse/OpenSSLSocketImpl.java

There is an setHostname() method in OpenSSLSocketImpl that if called
causes NativeCrypto.SSL_set_tlsext_host_name() to be called. That in
turn calls SSL_set_tlsext_host_name().

Hopefully, this is helpful.
title: Add SNI support for SSL hostname verification

I ever get the "Upload failed" notification with the InstantUpload function. In Wifi and in 3G.

I can upload manually any file on my Owncloud instance without any problem.
But the InstantUpload function is not working.

The fail alert is always sent after the upload process (i can the the upload working in the notification center, but at the end i get the error).

Precision : the InstantUpload folder is well created by the system on my owncloud instance.

With the app SendLog i have seen this kind of thing :

11-05 11:33:11.043 D/WebdavClient(16015): HEAD to /InstantUpload//20121105_113310.jpg finished with HTTP status 403(FAIL)
11-05 11:33:11.153 D/ChunkedUploadFileOperation(16015): Upload of /mnt/sdcard/DCIM/Camera/20121105_113310.jpg to /InstantUpload//20121105_113310.jpg, chunk index 0, count 27, HTTP result status 403
11-05 11:33:11.153 I/com.owncloud.android.operations.UploadFileOperation(16015): Upload of /mnt/sdcard/DCIM/Camera/20121105_113310.jpg to /InstantUpload//20121105_113310.jpg: Operation finished with HTTP status code 403 (fail)
11-05 11:33:11.158 D/PhotoTakenBroadcastReceiver(16015): Received: UPLOAD_FINISH

=> Double slash : /InstantUpload//20121105_113310.jpg
=> webdav403 failed

Any idea ?

Regards

body:
While testing the behaviour of down- and uploads with a single file File.txt for editing, I now noticed a spooky file File_conflict_20121030_084503.txt on the Android. 

I use
* server 4.5.1a
* Android 1.3.14
* Jota Text Editor (Android) with enabled setting to use abackup version when editing. This editor creates a backup file with filename File.txt~ . 

Perhaps this backup file (renaming, swapping names of current and backup version ???) is causing the reported issue. In previous tests I disabled the backup file creation in the Jota Text Editor settings and everything (editing on the server, editing in Windows client and editing on the Android device) appeared to work fine, at least I did not notice problems when synchronising the Android client manually - for this see https://github.com/bartoszprzybylski/owncloud-android/issues/43 )

The Delete button however only offers to the delete this particular file on the server(!).

The Windows client does not show such a file in the file list.

Questions:

* Please can you explain why the Android client offers "delete on the server" ?
* Should the text become "delete locally" because there is no File_conflict_TIMESTAMP.txt on the server but a conflicting backup file File.txt~ locally ? [UPDATE] I think I was wrong. The file is indeed on the server.
* This exact local file name (File.txt~) should be listed locally in the Android client, or File.txt~___conflict_TIMESTAMP [UPDATE]
I think I was wrong. The file is indeed on the server.
title: Files like File_conflict_TIMESTAMP.txt  when editing files on the Android device (Jota Text Editor)
